required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: A Comparison of CO2 Absorption During Gynecologic Laparoscopy Using the AirSeal® Valveless Trocar System Versus Standard Insufflation Trocars at Intra-abdominal Pressures of 10 mmHg and 15 mmHg - a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to compare carbon dioxide (CO2) absorption during gynecologic laparoscopy using the AirSeal® valveless trocar system versus standard insufflation trocars at intra-abdominal pressures of 10 and 15 mmHg.
The investigators hypothesize that with the AirSeal® valveless trocar system, gynecologic laparoscopy can be performed at a lower intra-abdominal pressure with a possible resultant decrease in CO2 absorption, while maintaining adequate visualization of the operative field for safe completion of surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
Three main factors affect patients' cardiopulmonary status during gynecologic laparoscopy: 1) degree of Trendelenburg tilt (25 - 30°), 2) carbon dioxide (CO2) absorption and 3) increased intra-abdominal pressure (10 -20 mmHg). Slight modifications to any or all of these three factors can lead to a significant decrease in morbidity.
The AirSeal® valveless trocar system reduces CO2 absorption when compared to standard trocars during renal laparoscopy. Also, use of this trocar system provides a more stable intra-abdominal pressure when compared to standard trocars, a feature that could possibly allow for laparoscopic surgery to be performed at lower intra-abdominal pressures.

primary_outcome.measure: Average Carbon Dioxide (CO2) Absorption During Gynecologic Laparoscopy Using the AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars at Intra-abdominal Pressures of 10 mmHg
primary_outcome.time_frame: 15 minutes & 60 minutes from surgery start time
primary_outcome.description: This outcome is measured by calculating the CO2 elimination rate. CO2 absorption rates were obtained at 15 and 60 minutes during each case and an average value was calculated per case. In cases < 60 minutes, the CO2 absorption rate at 15 minutes will be used.

secondary_outcome.measure: Median Surgeon Questionnaire Score When Using AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the end of surgery (approximately 1 hour)
secondary_outcome.description: Surgeon Questionnaire (0 "not adequate" -10 "optimal") is designed to evaluate the visualization of operative field by surgeon during colpotomy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With no Problem When Using AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the end of surgery (approximately 1 hour)
secondary_outcome.description: Anesthesia Questionnaire (0 "no problem" - 2 "very problematic) is designed to evaluate the the level of difficulty in maintaining adequate end-tidal CO2 (etCO2).

secondary_outcome.measure: Median VAS Pain Score When Using AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 4 to 6 hours, and 12 to 23 hours following surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (0 "no pain" - 10 "worst pain") is designed to evaluate the level of pain post-surgery.

secondary_outcome.measure: Average Carbon Dioxide (CO2) Absorption During Gynecologic Laparoscopy Using the AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars at Intra-abdominal Pressures of 15 mmHg
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 15 minutes & 60 minutes from surgery start time
secondary_outcome.description: This outcome is measured by calculating the CO2 elimination rate.

arm_group.description: Patients who are randomized into this arm will have their laparoscopic procedures performed with the standard trocar insufflator at an intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) of 15 mmHg.
Patients who are randomized into this arm will have their laparoscopic procedures performed with the standard trocar insufflator at an intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) of 10 mmHg.
Patients who are randomized into this arm will have their laparoscopic procedures performed with the AirSeal trocar insufflator at an intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) of 15 mmHg.
Patients who are randomized into this arm will have their laparoscopic procedures performed with the AirSeal trocar insufflator at an intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) of 10 mmHg.

intervention.description: The AirSeal® trocar is a valveless trocar that has been designed to replace the "trap door" and silicone valve of standard trocars with a curtain of forced CO2 gas. With the AirSeal® trocar, escaping gas is collected at the proximal end of the trocar, filtered, and redirected into the peritoneal cavity to maintain the pressure differential. The result is an invisible barrier that instantaneously responds to changes in intra-abdominal pressure, either by allowing more CO2 inflow with pressure drops or by serving as a pressure relief valve during pressure spikes.

A standard insufflation trocar delivers CO2 into the abdominal cavity to create workspace and uses either a "trap door" or silicone valve to prevent the egress of CO2 during laparoscopy in order to maintain intra-abdominal pressures. The standard trocars are not equipped to respond to changes in the intra-abdominal pressures in order to trigger an increase or decrease in the flow rate of CO2 gas.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Any woman ≥ 18 years of age undergoing a gynecologic laparoscopic procedure
- Able to understand the consenting process and willing to participate in study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient unable to undergo laparoscopic procedure due to size of pathology or medical comorbidities
- Emergent surgery

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Standard Trocar/ IAP 15 mmHg
group.description: Patients who are randomized into this arm will have their laparoscopic procedures performed with the standard trocar insufflator at an intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) of 15 mmHg. Standard trocar: A standard insufflation trocar delivers CO2 into the abdominal cavity to create workspace and uses either a "trap door" or silicone valve to prevent the egress of CO2 during laparoscopy in order to maintain intra-abdominal pressures. The standard trocars are not equipped to respond to changes in the intra-abdominal pressures in order to trigger an increase or decrease in the flow rate of CO2 gas.

group.title: Standard Trocar/ IAP 10 mmHg
group.description: Patients who are randomized into this arm will have their laparoscopic procedures performed with the standard trocar insufflator at an intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) of 10 mmHg. Standard trocar: A standard insufflation trocar delivers CO2 into the abdominal cavity to create workspace and uses either a "trap door" or silicone valve to prevent the egress of CO2 during laparoscopy in order to maintain intra-abdominal pressures. The standard trocars are not equipped to respond to changes in the intra-abdominal pressures in order to trigger an increase or decrease in the flow rate of CO2 gas.

group.title: AirSeal Trocar/ IAP 15 mmHg
group.description: Patients who are randomized into this arm will have their laparoscopic procedures performed with the AirSeal trocar insufflator at an intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) of 15 mmHg. AirSeal trocar: The AirSeal® trocar is a valveless trocar that has been designed to replace the "trap door" and silicone valve of standard trocars with a curtain of forced CO2 gas. With the AirSeal® trocar, escaping gas is collected at the proximal end of the trocar, filtered, and redirected into the peritoneal cavity to maintain the pressure differential. The result is an invisible barrier that instantaneously responds to changes in intra-abdominal pressure, either by allowing more CO2 inflow with pressure drops or by serving as a pressure relief valve during pressure spikes.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Average Carbon Dioxide (CO2) Absorption During Gynecologic Laparoscopy Using the AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars at Intra-abdominal Pressures of 10 mmHg
outcome.description: This outcome is measured by calculating the CO2 elimination rate. CO2 absorption rates were obtained at 15 and 60 minutes during each case and an average value was calculated per case. In cases < 60 minutes, the CO2 absorption rate at 15 minutes will be used.
outcome.time_frame: 15 minutes & 60 minutes from surgery start time
outcome.population: 132 patients were enrolled and randomized into 1 of 4 study arms: standard insufflation/IAP 10 (S/10), standard insufflation/IAP 15 (S/15), valveless insufflation/IAP 10 (V/10), valveless insufflation/IAP 15 (V/15).

The standard trocars are not equipped to respond to changes in the intra-abdominal pressures in order to trigger an increase or decrease in the flow rate of CO2 gas.

AirSeal trocar: The AirSeal® trocar is a valveless trocar that has been designed to replace the "trap door" and silicone valve of standard trocars with a curtain of forced CO2 gas. With the AirSeal® trocar, escaping gas is collected at the proximal end of the trocar, filtered, and redirected into the peritoneal cavity to maintain the pressure differential. The result is an invisible barrier that instantaneously responds to changes in intra-abdominal pressure, either by allowing more CO2 inflow with pressure drops or by serving as a pressure relief valve during pressure spikes.

AirSeal trocar: The AirSeal® trocar is a valveless trocar that has been designed to replace the "trap door" and silicone valve of standard trocars with a curtain of forced CO2 gas. With the AirSeal® trocar, escaping gas is collected at the proximal end of the trocar, filtered, and redirected into the peritoneal cavity to maintain the pressure differential. The result is an invisible barrier that instantaneously responds to changes in intra-abdominal pressure, either by allowing more CO2 inflow with pressure drops or by serving as a pressure relief valve during pressure spikes.

measure.title: Average Carbon Dioxide (CO2) Absorption During Gynecologic Laparoscopy Using the AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars at Intra-abdominal Pressures of 10 mmHg
measure.description: This outcome is measured by calculating the CO2 elimination rate. CO2 absorption rates were obtained at 15 and 60 minutes during each case and an average value was calculated per case. In cases < 60 minutes, the CO2 absorption rate at 15 minutes will be used.
measure.population: 132 patients were enrolled and randomized into 1 of 4 study arms: standard insufflation/IAP 10 (S/10), standard insufflation/IAP 15 (S/15), valveless insufflation/IAP 10 (V/10), valveless insufflation/IAP 15 (V/15).

outcome.title: Median Surgeon Questionnaire Score When Using AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars
outcome.description: Surgeon Questionnaire (0 "not adequate" -10 "optimal") is designed to evaluate the visualization of operative field by surgeon during colpotomy.
outcome.time_frame: At the end of surgery (approximately 1 hour)
outcome.population: 132 patients were enrolled and randomized with 33 patients per arm. The participants were women ≥ 18 years old undergoing non-emergent conventional or robotic gynecologic laparoscopic surgery.

measure.title: Median Surgeon Questionnaire Score When Using AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars
measure.description: Surgeon Questionnaire (0 "not adequate" -10 "optimal") is designed to evaluate the visualization of operative field by surgeon during colpotomy.
measure.population: 132 patients were enrolled and randomized with 33 patients per arm. The participants were women ≥ 18 years old undergoing non-emergent conventional or robotic gynecologic laparoscopic surgery.
measure.units: score on a scale from 0 to 10

outcome.title: Number of Participants With no Problem When Using AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars
outcome.description: Anesthesia Questionnaire (0 "no problem" - 2 "very problematic) is designed to evaluate the the level of difficulty in maintaining adequate end-tidal CO2 (etCO2).
outcome.time_frame: At the end of surgery (approximately 1 hour)
outcome.population: Women ≥ 18 years old undergoing non-emergent conventional or robotic gynecologic laparoscopic surgery.

measure.title: Number of Participants With no Problem When Using AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars
measure.description: Anesthesia Questionnaire (0 "no problem" - 2 "very problematic) is designed to evaluate the the level of difficulty in maintaining adequate end-tidal CO2 (etCO2).
measure.population: Women ≥ 18 years old undergoing non-emergent conventional or robotic gynecologic laparoscopic surgery.

outcome.title: Median VAS Pain Score When Using AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars
outcome.description: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (0 "no pain" - 10 "worst pain") is designed to evaluate the level of pain post-surgery.
outcome.time_frame: 4 to 6 hours, and 12 to 23 hours following surgery
outcome.population: Post-operative shoulder pain of women ≥ 18 years old undergoing non-emergent conventional or robotic gynecologic laparoscopic surgery.

measure.title: Median VAS Pain Score When Using AirSeal® Versus Standard Trocars
measure.description: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Pain Score (0 "no pain" - 10 "worst pain") is designed to evaluate the level of pain post-surgery.
measure.population: Post-operative shoulder pain of women ≥ 18 years old undergoing non-emergent conventional or robotic gynecologic laparoscopic surgery.
measure.units: score on a scale from 0 to 10

outcome.time_frame: 15 minutes & 60 minutes from surgery start time
outcome.population: Women ≥ 18 years old undergoing non-emergent conventional or robotic gynecologic laparoscopic surgery.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
